About Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary

Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary, located at 814 Headland Avenue, Dothan, AL, 36303, is a trusted and compassionate funeral home that has been serving the community for many years. With a commitment to providing exceptional service and care, the mortuary has established itself as a pillar of support for families during their most difficult times.

A Legacy of Excellence

Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary has built a reputation for excellence in funeral services, earning the trust of families from all walks of life. The mortuary's experienced staff is dedicated to providing personalized attention to every family they serve, ensuring that each ceremony is tailored to meet their unique needs and preferences.

Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary

Address: 814 Headland Avenue, Dothan, AL, 36303

Phone Number: 1-334-677-7200

Get Direction: Google Maps Link

Recent Funeral Home Obituaries

Rosa Mae Martin - January 29, 1934 - April 15, 2022

Departed: 04/15/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Ms. Rosa Martin, age 88, of Dothan, Alabama passed away Friday, April 15, 2022. Drive through visitation will be held on Friday, April 22, 2022 from 3 PM to 5 PM at the Funeral Home. Funeral service will be held on Saturday, April 23, 2022 at 11 AM at Stringer Street AME Church, 1900 Stringer Street, Dothan, Alabama 36303 with burial immediately following at North Highland Church Cemetery, 1110 Montana Street, Dothan, Alabama 36303. Mrs. Rosa Mae Martin (also affectionally called Ma’ Dear) was born on January 29, 1934, to the late Jetto (Curry) Brown and Roosevelt Brown in Houston County, Alabama. Her early years of life were spent as a Cosmetologist and doing other carious jobs. She retired from Ansell’s; where she worked there for over 35 years from Pearlie’s 24 hour sitting service. She attended Stringer Street AME Church; where she was an active member until her health started failing. She was Choir President, a member of the Women’s Missionary, and worked in the kitchen ministry for many years. Some of her enjoyments and hobbies were cooking, fishing, decorating, singing, helping, and entertaining others. She loved her brothers, sisters, children, grandchildren, family, and friends. She was preceded in death by her parents; husband: Charlie Ray Martin; her sisters: Mildred Harris and Christel Stanley; her brothers: Randall Brown, elmer Brown, and Charlie Ray Brown; her cousins like her brothers: Billie Trotter and James Earl Walker; her sister-in-law: Cynthia Brown, Johnnye O. Dunbar and Sabre L. Teague,; brother-in-law: Hayward Stanley; her son-in-law: Freddie L. Johnson, Sr.; her grandson: Lorenzo D. Martin; and her granddaughter: Mitchelle (Shelly) Martin. She leaves to cherish her precious memories three daughters: Carrie Johnson of Dothan, Alabama, Patricia (Donald) Franklin of Dothan, Alabama and Nina Martine of Miami, Florida; one son: Willie Charles Martin of Dothan, Alabama; grandchildren: Iris Johnson of Dothan, Alabama, Tyrone Martin of O’Fallon, Mo, Kimvatta Martin of Atlanta, Georgia, Freddie Johnson of Dothan, Alabama, Antonio T. Johnson of Dothan, Alabama and Dr. Freeman (LaRhonda) Culver of Glenpool, Oklahoma; great-grandchildren: Xavier Johnson of Dothan, Alabama, Rosteaua (Adrian) Thomas of Atlanta, Georgia, April (Josh) Bighems of Dothan, Alabama, Treasure Martin of Jacksonville, Florida, Ja’Quaria Johnson of Dothan, Alabama, Isaiah Martin of Dallas, Texas, Turquoise Martin of San Antonio, Texas, Carley Rae Martin and Tanner Martin, Tyler Martin all of O’Fallon, MO, Jaylin Johnson of Dothan, Alabama, Ja’Nayia Howard of Dothan, Alabama, Navadney Brown of Dothan, Alabama, Freedom Winnie Culver and Tyra Julia Culver all of Glenpool, OK; a host of great-great grandchildren that covered five generation; her siblings: Yvette (Robert) Lee of Rochester, New York and Yvonne Russ of Cleveland, Ohio; brothers: William David Brown of Rochester, New York, Leonard Brown of Rochester, New York, and Willie Cleveland (Helga) Brown of Germany; sister-in-law: Bonnie Branham of Dothan, Alabama and Lillian Brown of Miami, Florida; her best friend: Maude McNeall special like daughter: Jackie Hall; a host of nieces, nephews, cousins and other relatives and friends.

View Full Obituary

Rosie McNealy - April 21, 1932 - April 11, 2022

Departed: 04/11/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Ms. Rosie Mae McNealy of Dothan, Alabama passed away Monday, April 11,2022 at the age of 89. Public visitation will be held on Monday, April 18, 2022 from 4-6 PM. Funeral Service will be held on Tuesday April 19, 2022 at 1:00 PM at Greater Shiloh Baptist Church; 12 Martin Luther King Drive, Headland, Alabama 36345 with burial immediately following at Center Baptist Church Cemetery; 4344 State Highway 173, Newville, Alabama 36353 under the direction of the caring staff of Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary "Because We Care". Those we Love don’t Go away; they walk Beside us everyday. Unheard but always near, still loved, still missed and very dear. Rosie Mae McNealy was born in Henry County, Alabama to the late Hezzie and Rena Walker on April 21, 1932. Rosie, a resident of Dothan, Alabama passed away peacefully on April 11, 2022; she was 89. Rosie retired from what is now Golden Oil Mill, where she always believed in hard work and determination. In 1955, Rosie married the late J.C. McNealy and from their beloved union, Rosie conceived five beautiful children. Rosie was a member of the Greater Shiloh Missionary Baptist Church and served as a member until her glorious transition. Rosie was preceded in death by her parents, two children: Jerry and Marie McNealy; two sisters: Jenny Reddick and Mavis “Money” Walker; three brothers: Robert “Bob” Walker, Alvin “A.D.” Walker Otis ”Red” Walker, one granddaughter: Lakesha McNealy Knight; one nephew: Robert “Doc” Walker and one dear and special friend: Robert “Rob” Lee Norton. She leaves to cherish her motherly and loving memories, two sons: Earnest and Billy (Mari) McNealy; one daughter: Brenda Lee McNealy; three sisters: Ozie (Albert) Holloway of Dothan, Alabama, Jessie (M.C.) Lee of Dothan, Alabama and Joyce (Willie Floyd) King of Atlanta, Georgia; one brother: John (Mary) Walker of Buffalo, New York; grandkids: LaWanda Walker, Lashay (Vernon) Snell, Valerie Walker, LaToya Denise McNealy, Rashawn McNealy, Myleesia McNealy, Khristian McNealy, Kelandra McNealy, Tytrez McNealy and Jaelen McNealy; great-grandkids: Taran Rahjon McNealy, Shanyah Fluellen, Tavarion “TJ” Knight, Valisiana Snell, Jeremiah McNealy, Elijah McNealy, Taliah Sincere Knight, Cayden D. Snell, Leilani McNealy and Kaycen Chappell; three special nephews: James Earl Walker, Michael Lee and Stenet Gordan; one special niece: Betty Baxter; one special god-son: Joe Reynolds; two special sisters-in-law: Geraldine “Byrd” Thomas and Lucy Gordan and brother-in-law: Nathaniel McNealy, including a host of many nephews, nieces, cousins, family and acquaintances.

View Full Obituary

Tressie Streeter - April 16, 1933 - April 09, 2022

Departed: 04/09/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mrs. Tressie Mae Streeter, of Dothan, Alabama passed away Saturday, April 9, 2022 at the age of 88. Walk through visitation will be held on Friday, April 15, 2022 from 4-6PM at the Funeral Home. Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, April 16, 2022 at 12 Noon at New Bethel Missionary Baptist Church; 1100 Allen Road, Dothan, Alabama 36303; with burial immediately following at Gates of Heaven Cemetery; 2106 Starling Road, Dothan, Alabama 36303 under the caring staff of Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary "Because We Care". Mrs. Tressie Mae Streeter was born on April 16, 1933, to the late James Ezell Brown and the late Mary Bell Safford, in Abbeville, Alabama. She accepted Christ at an early age and was a faithful member of New Bethel Missionary Baptist Church until her resting day. If you knew Tressie, you couldn't help but to love her. She was loving, kind, and had a sense of humor you wouldn't soon forget. More importantly, she loved her family especially her five girls. She made sure they had not only what they needed but most of the things they wanted. She was an awesome cook and in fact, owned her own cafe, "Little Savoy Cafe". Prior to her retirement, she worked for Sony Magnetics and Hazel Hurst Laundry. She was preceded in death by her parents: James Ezell (Orrie) Brown and Mary Bell (John A.) Glover-Brown-Saffold; her "forever" husband: Master Sergeant Chester Streeter; her loving daughter: Mary E. Hollis; a praying granddaughter: Tiffany L. Hollis; her loving grandson: Rashad K. Streeter; her brothers: Willie Brown, Tommy Brown, Joe-Nathan Brown, Whitter Saffold, and Henry "Black" Safford; and her sisters: Mary Gibson and Johnnie Mae Sherryll. Continuing to celebrate her life, she leaves to cherish her memories, her loving daughters: Blanche (Byron) Alford, Brenda (Robert) Streeter Henry, Tammi (Mark) Breymeyer, and Nicole (Eulas) Black; her loving sisters: Elizabeth Branch, Lorene Saffold, Sarah (Leroy) Alford, and Joan (Charles) Wilcox; her loving brothers: Johnnie (Earnestine) Saffold, and Mechell (Theresa) Saffold; her granddaughters: Teadrian Hollis, Tamina Hollis, and Alexia Smith; her grandsons: Davian Smith, LaKendric Streeter, LaDarrian (Kathi) Smith, Jamian Smith, Nicholas (Willtresca) Streeter, and Joshua Black; 16 great grandchildren, 5 great great grandchildren, two special cousins: Annie Francis Carter and Johnnie B. Hollis, and a host of nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends.

View Full Obituary

Sandra Dawsey - October 04, 1983 - April 07, 2022

Departed: 04/07/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Ms. Sandra Dawsey, of Ashford, Alabama passed away Thursday, April 7, 2022 at the age of 38. Drive Through Visitation will be held on Thursday, April 14, 2022 from 4-6 PM at the Funeral Home. Funeral Service will be held on Friday, April 15, 2022 at 11:00 AM at Greater Beulah Missionary Baptist Church; 254 Headland Avenue, Dothan, Alabama 36303 with burial immediately following at Piney Grove Missionary Baptist Church Cemetery; 5 Piney Grove Church Road, Webb, Alabama 36376 under the direction of the caring staff of Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary "Because We Care". Sandra Denice Dawsey was born October 4, 1983 to the late Carrie Bell Dawsey and Sammie Lee Corbitt. She was a member of Piney Grove Missionary Baptist Church, where she joined at an early age and accepted the Lord Jesus Christ as her Savior. Sandra was a 2002 graduate of Dothan High School. She worked several years at Jack's Drugs as a pharmacy tech before continuing her education at Wallace Community College, where she obtained an Associate Degree in Early Childhood Education and a Bachelor's Degree from Rasmussen College. She was able to expand her knowledge and skills with the Dothan City School Head Start, Cottonwood Elementary, and Sunrise Elementary in South Florida. She had a big heart for her students and was passionate about her teachings. She had so much love being poured into her daily and her family meant everything to her. Her sassiness, her presence, her love, and her smile are what we will miss most of all. In addition to her beloved mother, Sandra was preceded into eternal rest by her devoted brother: Daniel Dawsey; loving grandfather: David Aaron; great grandmother: Fannie Mae Neal; and grandmother: Sadie Holt. She had so many others who loved her unconditionally that will truly miss her, including: Father: Sammie Corbitt; siblings: Johnny Dawsey, LaTonja Dawsey-Robinson, Lisa (Travis) Dawsey-Baker, Kim (Brian) Fields, Aprill (Kentay) Pittman, Jessica (Solomon) Dawsey of Atlanta, Georgia, Krystal Dawsey, and Marcus (Regina) Whitfield; Nieces and Nephews: she enjoyed to FaceTime with: Keyshon, Davonta "DJ" both of Tampa, Florida, Kenjana, Aliyah, Heidi, Brianna, Ja'Kory, Ty'Relle, Kameron, Trey, Taylan, Imani, Kameia, Makinley, Levi, Zahairia, Briaunah, Kehion, Nathaniel, Myeshia, Marquez, and Kylen; Grandparents: Thelma Dawsey of Dothan, Alabama and Janice Aaron of Chicago, Illinois; Special Aunts: Lillie Taplin, Luretha Laws, Thelma (Billie) Thomas, Louise Thomas of Dothan, Alabama; Very special cousins: Veronica and Francis McKnight of Dothan, Alabama; Godmother and Godsister: Elaine Pierce and Trakeyshua Pierce of Hillside, New Jersey; Bonded like sisters and brothers: LaKesha, Calvin (Candance), Tarsus, Ray J of Columbus, Ohio, Horace, Robert of Atlanta, Georgia, and Jazzilyn; Uncles/Aunts of love: David Aaron, Jr., Johnny Dawsey, Lawrence Dawsey, Dwight Dawsey, Ray (Lynn) Dawsey, Rev. James (Annie) Dawsey, Wiley Dawsey, Elder Michael Dawsey, Jowanna (JoAnn) Dawsey, Carolyn (Max) Parrish, Ira Jones of Hillside, New Jersey, and Shirley (Trawick) Hightower of Trenton, New Jersey; Best friend and Sister in love: Dameka Thompkins and Kim "Prince" Dawsey. Many other very loving great nieces, great nephews, aunts, uncles, other relatives and friends.

View Full Obituary

Annie Willie Miller - December 13, 1928 - April 03, 2022

Departed: 04/03/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Ms. Annie Willy Miller, age 94, of Dothan, Alabama passed away Sunday, April 3, 2022. Visitation will be held on Friday, April 8, 2022 from 4-6 PM at the funeral home. Graveside service will be held on Saturday, April 9, 2022 at 11:00 AM at Saint Luke Missionary Baptist Church Cemetery; 590 Saint Luke Road Fort Gaines, Georgia, under the direction of the caring staff of Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary "Because We Care". Annie Willie Miller was born on December 13, 1928, in Bluffton, Georgia, to the late Bailey Mathis and Beatrice Mathis. She confessed Christ at an early age and joined St. Luke Missionary Baptist Church in Ft. Gaines, Georgia, where she served faithfully until her passing. She received her education in the Bluffton County School System. In 1965, Annie Miller met Ed Miller in, in Bluffton, Georgia, and to this union, no children were born but her son was raised as their own. She worked as a housekeeper for 40 years. Her hobbies included having a loving relationship with her son, watching westerns, conversing with others, cooking and traveling in her younger years. She was preceded in death by her parents; sister: Annie Laura Irving of Blakely, Georgia; brother: Ben Brown of Fort Gaines, Georgia; and aunt: Edna Spann of Edison, Georgia. Annie leaves to cherish her memories, one son: Anthony Figgins of Dothan, Alabama; grandchildren: Brie Figgins and Breanna Figgins both of Tokyo, Japan; also survived by Minnie Brown of Syracuse, New York and Rose Glover of Ft. Gaines, Georgia; and a host of nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends.

View Full Obituary

Peter Wiggins - September 10, 1959 - April 02, 2022

Departed: 04/02/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mr. Peter Wiggins, age 62, of Jackson, New Jersey, passed away Saturday, April 2, 2022.

Mavis Daniels - July 04, 1927 - April 01, 2022

Departed: 04/01/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mrs. Mavis Jean Daniels, of Dothan, Alabama passed away Friday, April 1, 2022 at the age of 94. Visitation will be held on Friday, April 8, 2022 from 4-6PM at the Funeral Home. Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, April 9, 2022 at 11 AM at Georgette L. Scott Memorial Chapel; 814 Headland Avenue, Dothan, Alabama 36303 with burial immediately following at Gates of Heaven Cemetery; 2106 Starling Road, Dothan, Alabama 36303 under the direction of the caring staff of Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary "Because We Care". "Tomorrow and forever, I'll be just as I've always been - Myself" (Mavis Daniels) Of this life, there were no wasted years. Here was one who could be depended upon for whatever was right, worthy, and practical. Her life was fruitful and liberal. She was one who you could get to know and love. Her life touched the lives of so many children. She ministered to the needs of people in words and in deeds, always giving good account of herself. Truly a great personality has passed from among us leaving a vacancy that cannot be easily filled. Mrs. Mavis Kirkland Daniels, the tenth child of eleven children, was born in Henry County, Newville, Alabama, to the late Joseph and Teresa Lee Kirkland. Reared by Christian parents, she joined the Mt. Sinai Baptist Church in Newville at an early age. Later, as a young adult, she moved her membership to the First Missionary Baptist Church in Dothan, Alabama; where she sang in the choir, served on the Trustee Board, taught Sunday School, served with the Deacons Wives, the Lola Lunsford Prayer Board - where she served as secretary, and the Missionary Society Circle #4 - where she also served as secretary. She remained an active member until her health declined. On June 3, 1959, she was united in marriage to the late Roy Daniels. To this union, one son was born. Mavis attended elementary and high school in Henry County. She earned a bachelor's degree in elementary education from Clark College (now Clark Atlanta University) in Atlanta, Georgia, and taught school in the Dothan City Schools (North Highland, Montana Street Elementary and Selma Elementary) for 42 years. She was a loving, caring teacher and many of her students would often stop to tell her how much she touched their lives over the years. She retired from teaching in 1992. Selma Street Elementary School proclaimed May 18, 1992 "Mavis Daniels Day". Mavis was a member of the local, state, and national Retired Teachers Associations. She was a Charter Member of the Amy Washington Chapter #858, Order of the Eastern Star in 1967. She was a member active for 55 years and was a Past Treasurer of the Organization. Her parents: Joseph and Teresa Lee Kirkland; and siblings: Tinnie, Gertrude, Daisy, Jimmie, Lee Ella, Marie, Lucile, Keith, Kenneth, and Marvin preceded her in death. On the evening of April 1, 2022, Mavis answered the call of the Lord to claim her crown. We know she is resting in Heaven, reunited with her family. She leaves to cherish her sweet memory one son: Roderick B. Daniels of Dothan, Alabama; one granddaughter: Kamryn Daniels of Chicago, Illinois; one grandson: Colin Daniels of Chicago, Illinois; a special nephew, who was like a son to her: Michael B. (Letetia) Jackson of Dothan, Alabama and a host of nieces, nephews, and friends. Her favorite Bible verse, which she quoted often, is: "Do not be deceived, God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap." Galatians 6:7 KJV.

View Full Obituary

Thomas J. Turner - June 04, 1940 - March 27, 2022

Departed: 03/27/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mr. Thomas Turner, age 81, of Pansey, Alabama passed away Sunday, March 27, 2022. Memorial Service will be held on Friday, April 8, 2022 at 5 PM at the Funeral Home; 814 Headland Avenue Dothan, Alabama 36303 under the direction of the caring staff of Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary "Because We Care". Deacon Thomas J. Turner was born on June 4, 1940, in Troy, Alabama, to Allen Turner, Sr. and Annie Glen White Turner. Deacon Turner attended Ashford High School in Ashford, Alabama. After graduating from the police academy and relocating to Ithaca, New York, Officer Turner's primary patrol was Cornell University. His photograph was entered into High School History books; so great was his dedication to the force. For numerous years Deacon Turner worked at MacCormick Juvenile Correctional Center, medically retiring in 1994. While in Ithaca in the mid to late 1960's he became a member of Calvary Baptist Church where he was the founding member of Calvary's Transportation Ministry. Deacon Turner was deeply concerned about Cornell University students' inability to attend their home churches. Beginning with the Ujamaa dormitory where many Black students resided, he made several stops each Sunday, both before and after service so no student had to miss the Word of God. He was also ordained a church deacon, serving as Chairman of the Deacon Board for several years, and was a faithful member of the male chorus. He also served communion after church, each 1st Sunday, to the sick and shut in. An avid farmer, Deacon Turner owned farmland in both Freeville, New York and Pansey, Alabama. Deacon Turner was an integral participant in farming culture and innovation, receiving several Federal grants while working closely with Tuskegee Institute in Tuskegee, Alabama, in both agricultural archetype and student attrition. Deacon Turner was a passionate advocate on behalf of farming, attended numerous such conferences, instituted an annual forum for Black farmers and mentored area youth and adults. Upon returning to Alabama, after long years of inerrant community and sacred service, Deacon Turner served faithfully at Pilgrim Rest Baptist Church. Deacon Thomas J. Turner has four children: Arnold Turner of Elmira, New York (deceased), Randall Turner of Ithaca, New York, Thomasena Taylor (Fern) of Covington, Georgia, and Melissa Turner of New York, New York. His siblings include: Mildred Lee Caldwell of Rivera, Florida (deceased), Allen Turner, Jr of Clayton, Alabama (deceased), Katiemae Gaston of Hillside, New Jersey (deceased), Annie Pearl Telfair of Ashford, Alabama, Allen Wilburt Turner of West Palm Beach, Florida (deceased), Samuel Turner of West Palm Beach, Florida, Willie Glen Turner of Buffalo, New York (deceased), Catherine Turner of Ashford, Alabama and a host of grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends.

View Full Obituary

James Edwards - September 30, 1941 - March 27, 2022

Departed: 03/27/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mr. James Ennis Edwards, age 80, of Ozark, Alabama passed away Sunday, March 27, 2022. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, April 5, 2022 at 1 PM at J.L. Trawick Memorial Chapel, 1048 Martin Luther King Jr. Ave, Ozark, Alabama 36360. James Ennis Edwards was born in Skipperville, Alabama, on September 30, 1941. James attended school in Skipperville, Alabama. At a young age, he accepted Christ as his Lord and Savior. He was united in Holy Matrimony to the late Annie Dora McLeod Edwards. To this union, one daughter was born: Deborah Ann Edwards. The couple joined and were faithful members of St. Paul AME Church; where he served as an Usher and was a member of the male choir. In his spare time, he enjoyed fishing and was a part of the Ozark professional bowling league. He was a devoted husband, father, family member and friend to many. James was preceded in death by his parents: Algertha Butler and John Henry Edwards; his guardian: Mozell Clark; wife: Annie Edwards; one sister: Myrtis Anderson; and one brother: Lovett Johnson. He is survived by his loving daughter: Deborah (Rodrick) Edwards Morgan; one grandchild: Michael T. Barker, Sr.; five great grandchildren: Olivin Barker, Michael Barker, Jr., Emily Barker, Ethan Barker, and Deondre Mclendon; four siblings: Kelvin Butler, Cheryl (Earl) Bennett, Stepon (Valerie) Butler, and Catherine Fleming all of Nashville, Tennessee; sister-in-law: Viola Byrd; special friend: Leray Johnson; and a host of nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends.

View Full Obituary

Wilbur McKay - May 18, 1937 - March 24, 2022

Departed: 03/24/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Ms. Wilbur McKay, age 84, of Newville, Alabama passed away Thursday, March 24, 2022. Visitation will be Tuesday, March 29, 2022 4-6 PM at the funeral home. Graveside will be held on Wednesday, March 30, 2022 at 11 AM at the Mt. Sinai Missionary Baptist Church Cemetery, Newville, AL under the direction of the caring staff of Scott's Chapel Hill Mortuary "Because We Care". Mrs. Wilbur Louise Humphrey McKay was born on May 18, 1937, in Newville, Alabama to the parentage of the late Willie Frank and Vera B. Humphrey. Wilbur was married to the late Carl E. McKay and to this union two daughters were born, Sandranetta and Shalonda (Shawn). At an early age she confessed her love for Christ and joined Mount Sinai Baptist Church in Newville, Alabama where she served as Sunday School Teacher, Matron, member of the Missionary Society, and Food Bank Coordinator. Wilbur graduated Valedictorian of her class from Newville Rosenwald School at the age of 15 years old. She earned her bachelor and masters degrees from Alabama State University, Montgomery, Alabama. She was employed by the Henry County Training School and Headland Middle School where she impacted her students through her love of education and discipline. She retired after 41 years of dedicated service to the students of Henry County. She was a member of Alpha Pi Chi National Sorority, Inc. and the Order of Eastern Star, Lookwell Chapter #219, Past Worthy Matron. She served her community faithfully as Newville City Councilwoman and Mayor Pro Tempore. In addition to being a dedicated and loving mother and grandmother, Wilbur also enjoyed gardening, fishing, walking, traveling, spending time with family and friends, and the frequent casino trip. Wilbur touched the lives of many with her words, compassion, and kindness. She was an outspoken woman with a passion for education and inspiring excellence in her students. She was a renowned orator and speech writer. Her love for her family and close friends was immense. She is preceded in death by her parents, and siblings: James Willis Humphrey, Gloria Ann Horne, and Juliette Lee. Wilbur departed this life on March 24, 2022. She leaves to cherish her wonderful memory: two devoted daughters, Sandranetta McKay Abney and Shalonda M. (Richard) Cass; granddaughters Jocelyn (Jessie) McAlpine and London Cass; grandson: Jordan Abney; niece: Tavion (Luther) Johnson; great niece: Taylor Johnson; nephews: Daniel L. Lee, Kenneth Humphrey, Bruce Humphrey, James Humphrey, Darryl Humphrey, Mickey Horne, Michael Horne, Martin McKay, Makylen Horne, and Austin Boyd. Devoted Godson: Rickey Allen. Devoted Goddaughter: Sherlyn Johnson. Devoted sister-n-law: Catherine McKay. Devoted family friends: Joe Fain, Mary Girtman, Elaine Hogans, Vivian Johnson, Lamont Lewis, Annie R. Russ, and Patricia Smith.

View Full Obituary

Dolphis Powell - December 11, 1963 - March 22, 2022

Departed: 03/22/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mr. Dolphis Powell of Dothan, Alabama passed away Tuesday, March 22, 2022 at the age of 58. Visitation will be Friday, March 25, 2022 from 4 PM to 6 PM at the funeral home. Dolphis Powell was born December 11, 1963, to the late John Thomas Powell, Sr. and the late Valonia Powell, in Columbia, Alabama. Dolphis loved family, friends, work and music. He was a jack-of-all-trade and could complete any task that he put his hands to. Dolphis married Karen Coleman and shared this love between their four children: Brittany Paige Coleman, Sidney Vance Coleman, Amanda Renee Powell, and Mallory Patrice Powell. Dolphis was a welder by trade most of his adult life, working for various companies. Prior to his demise, he became a handyman, helping various people in the community. He departed this life on Tuesday, March 22, 2022. Dolphis Powell was preceded in death by his parents: John Thomas Powell, Sr. and Valonia Powell; stepmother: Donnie Powell; and sister: Jannette Ardis. He leaves to cherish his memory, his former wife: Karen Powell; children: Brittany Paige Coleman, Sidney Vance Coleman, Amanda Renee Powell, and Mallory Patrice Powell; brothers: John Thomas (Sheila) Powell, Earnest (Monica) Powell both of Dothan, Alabama, and Edward Powell of Mt. Meig, Alabama; three sisters: Annie Bell (Eddie) West, Eddie Lee Powell of Columbia, Alabama, and Valona (Tracy) Womack of Albany, Georgia; one uncle: Amos Powell of Columbus, Georgia; and a host of nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends.

View Full Obituary

Robert Redding - June 07, 1941 - March 20, 2022

Departed: 03/20/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mr. Robert Earl Redding, 80 years old, of Dothan, Alabama passed away Sunday, March 20, 2022. Public visitation will be held on Friday, March 25, 2022 from 4-6 PM at the Funeral Home. Graveside Service will be held on Saturday, March 26, 2022 at 1 PM at Crestlawn Memorial Cemetery; 50 Crestlawn Circle Avon, AL 36312. On Saturday, June 7, 1941, Mr. Thomas and Mrs. Beurea Mae Redding became the proud parents of Robert Earl Redding in Ashford, Alabama. His primary education commenced at Ashford Colored School. A proud member of the Class of 1959. After graduation, he continued his studies. Robert excelled in his studies and furthered his education at Alabama State University. His area of concentration was Accounting. He, later, received his CPA license. Robert, realizing there were more lucrative employment opportunities in his field of study, moved to New York. Wall Street knew Robert was coming. Before the end of his initial interview, Robert was hired. His gift had made more room for him and presented him before great men. After working on Wall Street for five years, he furthered his employment career at Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA). He was employed with MTA until 1989 and retired after 20 years. After retirement, he moved back to Alabama. Not one to sit idly by, he continued working part-time. Robert was a faithful and devoted member of the Tabernacle Missionary Baptist Church; where he was a member of the Male Choir, under the leadership of Pastor Vincent T. Owens. He served there, faithfully, until his health declined. Robert met and married Gussie (Pitts) Redding and to this union, two lovely daughters were born: Tereska and Tara Redding. Robert met Barbara in 2015. Years later, this relationship blossomed into a beautiful, fragrant flower of marriage. As it pleased the Almighty God to call Robert's soul home, he departed this earthly life for eternal life on Sunday, March 20, 2022. He was preceded in death by his parents; and brothers: John A. Dawsey and Dwight Redding. He leaves to cherish his memories, his loving and devoted wife: Barbara Redding; daughters: Tereska Redding of Phoenix, Arizona and Tara Lopez of Neptune, New Jersey; granddaughter: Athena Redding-Morgan of Columbia, Carolina; brother: Trawick (Lillie) Redding of Ozark, Alabama; sister: Gloria Constance Sylvester of Tampa, Florida; sister-in-law: Lester Dawsey of Atlanta, Georgia; brother/cousin: Willie "Joe" Kirkland of Richland, South Carolina; and a host of nieces, nephews, cousins, and sorrowing family and friends.

Willie Ruth Ingram - July 02, 1949 - March 19, 2022

Reverend Paul Cowley - August 29, 1957 - March 11, 2022

Departed: 03/11/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Reverend Paul Edward Cowley, age 64, of Dothan, Alabama passed away Friday, March 11, 2022. Drive through visitation will be held on Friday, March 18, 2022 from 4-6 PM at the Funeral Home. Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, March 19, 2022 at 12 noon at New Bethel Missionary Baptist Church; 1110 Allen Road, Dothan, Alabama 36303. Burial will immediately follow the service at Sunset Memorial Park Cemetery. Pastor Paul E. Cowley was the son of the late Urias Cowley and the late Theola Sykes. He was born August 29, 1957, in Pine Bluff, Arkansas. He later moved to East St. Louis, Illinois with his family. After high school, he joined the United States Army and was stationed in Fort Rucker, Alabama; where he met his wife: Diane Stephens. They were married in Pirmasens, Germany in 1977 and traveled the world together. To this union, two sons: David Paul and Matthew Paul Cowley, were born. In 1990, he retired from the Army and relocated to Dothan, Alabama. After his retirement, he worked for Dothan City Schools. He accepted the call to the ministry in November, 1998, and was later employed by Wiregrass Hospice (later Gentiva) as Chaplain. He always said that he was so blessed to be able to do the Lord's work seven days a week. He retired for the second time in 2015. Throughout his ministry, he served as Assistant Pastor for Antioch Missionary Baptist Church in Newton, Alabama (1999-2003) and New Salem Missionary Baptist Church in Shorterville, Alabama (1998-2002). He was called as Pastor to Sardis Baptist Church in June of 2003 and continued there until his death. He often said, "You will know when you love the Lord because you can't help but love all God's people." Paul truly loved everyone. He not only pastored a church, but his ministry extended to several communities. His love for people guided him to volunteer with the Dothan Rescue Mission, the House of Ruth, Inc., Southeast Health Hospital, and several prisons throughout Alabama and Florida. He touched lives and hearts wherever he went. He was preceded in death by his parents: Urias Cowley and Theola Sykes; one brother: Murl Cowley; and one sister: Rosemary Cowley Roberts. He leaves to cherish his memory, his wife of 44 years: Diane Stephens Cowley; two sons: David Paul (Lorrissa) of Dothan, Alabama and Matthew Paul (Aisha) of Gainesville, Florida; one brother: Jimmy Linzy of Washington Park, Illinois; four sisters: Delorise Marks, Joyce Harden, Mary Ann Dozier all of Washington Park, Illinois and Barbara Ellison (Al) of Clarksville, Tennessee; three sisters-in-law: Ila Allen, Glenda (Bobbie) Ward, and Cynthia (James) Keyton all of Dothan, Alabama; two granddaughters: Arianna Diane and Aisha Diane both of Dothan, Alabama; and a multitude of nieces, nephews, and unofficially adopted children, all of whom he loved dearly.

Larry Ford - November 13, 1949 - March 08, 2022

Departed: 03/08/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mr. Larry Ford, age 72, of Dothan, Alabama passed away Tuesday, March 8, 2022. Drive through visitation will be Friday, March 11, 2022 from 4 PM to 6 PM at the funeral home. Funeral service will be held on Saturday, March 12, 2022 at 1 PM at Stringer Street AME Church, 1900 Stringer Street, Dothan, Alabama 36303. Burial will immediately follow the service at Gates of Heaven Cemetery. Larry Hugh Ford was born on November 13, 1949, to the late Jessie Ford and Ed Cox. He was a lifelong resident of Dothan, Alabama. On Tuesday, March 8, 2022, Larry Hugh Ford, husband, father, brother, uncle, and friend peacefully transitioned from this earthly life to eternity at the age of 72. Larry was a proud graduate of Carver High School Class of 1968. He was a dedicated employee for many years at Gates Power Drive and Dothan Country Club. In his later years, Larry was a successful entrepreneur; as he owned a lawn care service and faithfully served the needs of the community. Larry accepted Christ as his Lord and Savior at an early age and enjoyed serving in multiple ministries at church as well as in the community. He was a member of the Wiregrass Elks Lodge #810, Associate member of the Women Missionary Society, a lifelong member of Stringer Street AME Church, where he served with the Sons of Allen and was a member of the male chorus. Larry always had a smile on his face and was willing to help others. He was a generous man whom loved to fish, loved music, played the drums in high school and was the life of the party. He is best known for his culinary skills including his delicious collard greens and pecan pies. Larry was preceded in death by his mother, Jessie Ford and father, Ed Cox. His brothers, Preston Butts, Jackie Ford and Homer Lee Cox. His stepchildren, Rhonda Balton and Steven Balton. Larry is survived by his wife, Brenda Ford, daughter Vanessa Ford, son, Larry Ford, stepdaughters, April Potter, Charlotte Hicks (Mark), Lela Cooper (Arthur), step son Howard Balton. His siblings, Nettie Ree Cox and Willie Cox. His grandchildren Kourtlyn and Kamora Ford, Randall Baylor, Brandon Warner, Mark Hicks Jr.,Crystina Penn, Amani Cooper, Kenneth Balton Jr., Kenise Balton, Kenya Balton, and Gabriel and Emmanuel Bright. A host of nieces and nephews, cousins, and friends.

Obituary Preview: Mother Robie Spears, age 104, of Stamford, Connecticut; formerly a resident of Dothan, Alabama, passed away Saturday, March 5, 2022. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, March 13, 2022 at 2 PM at Georgette L. Scott Memorial Chapel, 814 Headland Avenue, Dothan, Alabama 36303. There, she worshipped at Wilson Memorial Church of God in Christ until her health prevented her from attending. She was a quiet, loving person who loved the Lord, cooking, and sharing. She was "Mom" to everyone that knew her; from the youngest to the oldest. Mary Thomas - July 29, 1931 - March 05, 2022

Departed: 03/05/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Mary Thomas, age 90, of Lakewood, New Jersey; former resident of Dothan, Alabama, passed away Saturday, March 5, 2022. Visitation will be one hour prior to the service on Tuesday, March 15, 2022 at the funeral home. Graveside service will be held on Tuesday, March 15, 2022 at 11 AM at Gates of Heaven Cemetery, 2106 Starling Road, Dothan, Alabama 36303. Mary Thomas, 90, of Lakewood, NJ was born on July 29, 1931, in Headland, Alabama to the late Clayton and Selfie Lee Thomas. Mary was the fourth of fifteen children of which seven preceded her in death. At an early age, Mary accepted Jesus Christ as her Lord and Savior and became a faithful member of Asbury Park Deliverance Evangelistic Center under the leadership of Apostle Herbert J. Sneed. She later became a faithful member of Pillars of Harvest Ministries, under the leadership of Pastor Antonious Thigpen, where they lovingly called her Mother Thomas. Mary was a domestic engineer for many years to care for her family. Her favorite Bible scripture was Deuteronomy 31:6- “Be strong and of good courage, do not fear nor be afraid of them: for the LORD your God, He is the One who goes with you. He will not leave you nor forsake you.” Her favorite song was Lee Williams – Steal My Joy, where we would always find ourselves praising the Lord right in the middle of the living room floor. Mary is survived by her six children, Larry Thomas (Carol), Orlando Thomas (Robbie), Betty Thomas (Michelle-deceased), Anita Crooks (Dave), Geraldine Allen (Martel), and Mae Thomas, eight grandchildren, Rockil Macon (T’Pring), Alicia Thomas (Andrew), Tiffany Thomas, Michelle Thomas, Malcolm Thomas, Patrick Thomas, Markus Thomas, and Deion Crooks, two great-grandchildren, Patrick Thomas Jr., and August Thomas to cherish many memories she shared with each of them, siblings, whom she loved dearly, Mellinee Walker of Lakewood, NJ, Ophelia Walker of Lakewood, NJ, Betty Hamilton of Coco Beach, FL, Mable Simpson of Melborne, FL, Jerry Thomas of Vero Beach, FL and Wade Thomas of Headland, AL, and a host of nieces, nephews, relatives, and friends.

Juliette Elleen Jones - September 22, 1951 - February 26, 2022

Departed: 02/26/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, March 8, 2022 11:00 AM at the Georgette L. Scott Memorial Chapel, 814 Headland Ave, Dothan, Alabama. Juliette Elleen Jones was born September 22, 1951, to Elijah C. (aka E.C.) and Jewel Rosebud Jackson Jones. She was the fourth of five siblings. Juliette accepted Christ as her personal Savior at an early age and became a member of First Missionary Baptist Church, Dothan, where she was baptized and remained a member throughout life. Juliette attended Dothan City Schools and graduated from George Washington Carver High School in 1968. Juliette was very smart and as a young student was allowed to skip a grade in elementary school and received scholarships to attend summer school sessions in North Carolina. She was the Valedictorian of her high school class and a majorette in the G.W. Carver Roarin' Lions Marching Band among other extracurricular and scholastic activities. After high school, she was a scholarship recipient to attend North Carolina A&T State University where she graduated in 1972 with her Bachelor's Degree in Political Science. While attending A&T, she pledged and became a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. She loved her pink and green. She also studied at the graduate level at Georgia State University. Juliette began her professional work career in Alexandria, Virginia working for the US federal government. She continued that career path in Atlanta, Georgia. She worked for Michelin originally in South Carolina before her supervisory assignment at the Dothan location. She worked several other jobs too - her last being with the Alabama Department of Human Resources, Dothan office before retirement. Juliette loved to dance. She inherited that from her daddy. They would often cut a step together. Juliette started taking dance lessons when she was a little girl. If a song touched her rhythmic soul, she got up and moved to the beat. It didn't matter if she was at church or somewhere else. She definitely showed her rhythmic prowess as she strutted in front of the Marching Roarin' Lions Band at football games and homecoming and National Peanut Festival Parades. Juliette also loved to choreograph dance routines and shared her love for choreography through various praise dance groups in Dothan and the Wiregrass area. She also loved developing choreography routines for the Dothan Genteel Beaux: Young Men of Distinction and Debutantes. Juliette is preceded in death by her father and mother, E.C. and Jewel; grandparents Walter and Rosa Jones and SyRossi and Talesta Harris; siblings Talesta, Reginald, Ronald, Ronald’s second wife Barbara Dennis Jones, and a special brother James Thomas. Those who will forever miss her include: brother Elton Charles Jones (Laurita); several nieces and nephews: Shervonda, Reginald (Touannette), Beyunca, Dameon, Brittney, Ellington, Jennifer, Nicole, Rone’, and Duane; several great-nieces and great-nephews: Zicarrio, Portaque, DreShawn, Raymon, De’Shawn, Brenton, Jeremy, Ieron, Renette, and Juan; great-great nephews Zicarrias, TK; God-sister Helen Awls; first sister-in-law, Bessie McDaniel; a special neighbor and friend Turesea Johnson, and many other friends and relatives. On February 26, 2022, we discovered that Juliette had begun her immortal celebration.

Obituary Preview: Mrs. Glenda Rhodes was born on September 18, 1945, in Dothan, Alabama to James and Eula Mae Beachum Britt. Mrs. Rhodes dedicated her life to Jehovah on August 8, 1979. Rhodes, Sr., they were joined in Holy Matrimony on October 17, 1963, in Newark, New Jersey. Howard Earl Mason - September 26, 1952 - February 24, 2022

Departed: 02/24/2022 (Dothan)

Obituary Preview: Staff Sergeant Howard Earl Mason served in the United States Air Force until his retirement. Howard Earl was a loving, caring, devoted father, brother, uncle and friend who passed away peacefully at his home in Dothan, Alabama on February 16, 2022. He received his education in the Franklin, Virginia school system where he graduated in 1972. He gave his life to the Lord at a very young age, and he attended the White Oaks Spring Church while residing in Franklin, VA. To know “Howard Earl” was to love him. He was such a great man and certainly a big kid at heart. He was such a jokester; He loved making anyone laugh that he’d encounter and was so full of LOVE. He had such a nurturing and fun-loving spirit, and we all knew how much he loved children. He had a fond love for cartoons, fixing cars and listening to jazz as well as being a lover of all foods, and please don’t forget his orange drinks. All that knew our Howard Earl loved him. Earl, as he was affectionally known, was born to Albertha Mason (mother), Herman Frank Mason (father) on September 26, 1952. He was preceded in death by parents; his brother, Herman “TJ” Mason (Frances). Left to cherish his memories are four sisters: Mary Alice Bostic of Maryland, Delois Hart (Tyrone) of Virginia Beach, VA, Linda Riddick (Gilbert) of Franklin, VA, and Pamala Bynum (Larry) of Franklin, VA; two brothers, Frederick A. Cross (Angela) of Suffolk, VA, and Roy Cross (Carolyn) of Franklin, VA; his daughter, Sharon Britt Eley; Earl had a fond love for all of his family and had a special place in his heart for his aunt Cassie and his niece Nakia Johnson including a host of nieces, nephews, great-nieces, great-nephews, cousins, and many friends who will miss him dearly. There will be a Zoom Memorial for Howard Earl Mason on Friday, March 4, 2022 at 7:00pm SHARP! Arrangements will be private. Sorrowfully submitted, the Family! The Family of Howard Earl Mason would like to thank everyone for their prayers and kindness during this time.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is an obituary?

An obituary is a written notice that announces the death of a person, typically including their name, age, date of birth and death, and other biographical information. It may also include details about their life, accomplishments, and surviving family members.

Why are obituaries important?

Obituaries serve as a way to inform friends, family, and community members of a person's passing, allowing them to pay their respects and offer condolences. They also provide a sense of closure and can be a meaningful way to celebrate the life of the deceased.

Who writes an obituary?

Typically, the family of the deceased or a close friend will write the obituary. In some cases, a funeral home or mortuary may assist with writing the obituary or provide a template for the family to use.

What information should be included in an obituary?

A typical obituary includes the person's name, age, date of birth and death, place of residence, occupation, education, military service (if applicable), and surviving family members. It may also include hobbies, interests, achievements, and other personal details.

How long should an obituary be?

The length of an obituary can vary depending on the publication or online platform where it will be published. Generally, it should be concise and to the point, ranging from a few sentences to a few paragraphs.

Can I include photos or other media in an obituary?

Yes, many publications and online platforms allow you to include photos, videos, or other multimedia elements in an obituary. This can help make the tribute more personal and engaging.

How do I submit an obituary to a newspaper or online platform?

The process for submitting an obituary varies depending on the publication or platform. Typically, you will need to contact the obituary department or submit through an online form. Be sure to follow any specific guidelines or requirements provided.

How much does it cost to publish an obituary?

The cost of publishing an obituary varies widely depending on the publication or platform. Some may offer free listings, while others may charge by the word or line. Expect to pay anywhere from $50 to several hundred dollars.

Can I write my own obituary in advance?

Yes, it is becoming increasingly common for people to write their own obituaries in advance. This can be a therapeutic exercise and ensure that your life is celebrated in the way you want.

What is the difference between an obituary and a death notice?

A death notice is a brief announcement of a person's passing, typically including only basic information such as name, age, and date of death. An obituary is a more detailed tribute that provides additional biographical information and context.

Can I include humor or lighthearted anecdotes in an obituary?

Absolutely! An obituary should reflect the personality and spirit of the deceased. Including humorous stories or anecdotes can help celebrate their life and make the tribute more engaging.

How do I handle sensitive or private information in an obituary?

If there are sensitive or private aspects of the deceased's life that you prefer not to share publicly, it's best to omit them from the obituary or discuss them discreetly with close family and friends.

Can I include charitable donations or memorial information in an obituary?

Yes, many families choose to include information about charitable donations or memorials in lieu of flowers. This can be a meaningful way to honor the deceased and support a worthy cause.

How long after someone passes away should an obituary be published?

The timing of publishing an obituary varies depending on cultural and personal preferences. Typically, it's published within a few days to a week after the person's passing.

Can I publish an obituary online only?

Yes, many people choose to publish obituaries online only, either through social media platforms, online memorial sites, or funeral home websites. This can be a cost-effective and environmentally friendly option.

What is an online memorial site?

An online memorial site is a digital platform where you can create a virtual tribute to a loved one who has passed away. These sites often allow you to share memories, photos, and stories about the deceased.

How do I find archived obituaries from years ago?

You can search online archives of newspapers or genealogy websites that specialize in collecting historical records. Local libraries or genealogical societies may also have access to archived materials.

Can I republish an old obituary on social media or online platforms?

Yes, you can republish an old obituary on social media or online platforms as a way to remember and honor the deceased on special occasions such as birthdays or anniversaries.

What is the etiquette for responding to an online obituary?

Can I include quotes or lyrics in an obituary?

Absolutely! Including meaningful quotes or song lyrics can add depth and emotion to an obituary. Choose something that resonates with the deceased's personality or spirit.

How do I ensure accuracy when writing an obituary?

To ensure accuracy when writing an obituary, verify facts with multiple sources whenever possible. Double-check dates, names, and other details to avoid errors.
